questions.text: A CT scan reveals periaortic soft tissue mass encasing both ureters. Regarding retroperitoneal fibrosis, which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Methysergide use is a recognized etiology in some cases.

options.label: B
options.text: Bilateral ureteric obstruction is best managed initially with bilateral nephrostomies.

options.label: C
options.text: Tamoxifen is contraindicated in the medical management of this condition.

options.label: D
options.text: Laparoscopic ureterolysis with omental wrapping is a surgical option for persistent cases.

questions.correct_answer: C. Tamoxifen is contraindicated in the medical management of this condition.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with abdominal distension, colicky pain that worsens after meals, and a gradual decline in her overall health. On examination, she has multiple hernias and ascites that do not demonstrate shifting dullness. Imaging reveals a jelly-like substance throughout the peritoneal cavity and mesentery. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Ascitic fluid due to liver cirrhosis

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with a history of liver cirrhosis presents with symptoms of chronic gastrointestinal bleeding, including anaemia and fatigue. Upper endoscopy is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE)

Portal Hypertensive Gastropathy (PHG)

Description

GAVE is a condition characterized by dilated blood vessels in the antrum of the stomach, often resembling the pattern of a watermelon.

PHG is a condition associated with portal hypertension, marked by a mosaic-like pattern of red and white spots on the stomach lining.

Endoscopic Appearance

Flat, reddish stripes radiating from the pylorus into the antrum, resembling a watermelon.

Vascular Ectasia: A Case Report and Literature Review. Journal of translational internal medicine. 6. 47-51. 10.2478/jtim-2018-0010. " data-hash="" data-license="CC BY-NC-ND 3.0" data-source="https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Striped-watermelon-appearance-of-gastric-antral-vascular-ectasia_fig4_324172241" data-tags="" height="388" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/ceLrQdqLO4EXNTLHrwal1739936044.png" width="400" />

A mosaic-like pattern of red and white spots on the stomach lining, typically in the fundus and upper body.

portal hypertensive gastropathy in ESRD patient with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease misdiagnosed as pericarditis. Journal of Renal Injury Prevention. 5. 48-52. 10.15171/jrip.2016.11. " data-hash="" data-license="CC BY 4.0" data-source="https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Shows-portal-hypertensive-gastropathy-PHG-changes-evident-on-upper-GI-endoscopy_fig3_298328872" data-tags="" height="400" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/KczSbIeeHDVwjMHB9cko1739936118.png" width="400" />

Association

Can occur in patients with cirrhosis, autoimmune disorders, and chronic renal failure

Always associated with portal hypertension

Prevalence in Cirrhosis

Low (around 2-8%)

Much more common

Histology

Dilated mucosal capillaries, fibrin thrombi, and spindle cell proliferation - vascular ectasia

Gastric mucosa showing dilated and distended capillaries

Management

Endoscopic ablation (e.g., Argon Plasma Coagulation, Endoscopic Band Ligation)

Reducing portal pressure (Option D)

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with sudden, massive hematemesis. An upper endoscopy identifies a small mucosal defect surrounded by normal gastric mucosa. Angiography reveals a large, tortuous artery in the left gastric artery distribution. What is the underlying pathophysiological mechanism of bleeding in Dieulafoy’s lesion?

options.label: A
options.text: Erosion of the mucosa due to excessive acid secretion

options.label: B
options.text: Rupture of varices caused by portal hypertension

options.label: C
options.text: Erosion of mucosa due to pulsations from a large submucosal artery

options.label: D
options.text: Ulceration of the gastric mucosa due to chronic use of NSAIDs

questions.correct_answer: C. Erosion of mucosa due to pulsations from a large submucosal artery
questions.explanation:
Dieulafoy’s lesion
  • Dieulafoy's lesion is characterized by an abnormally large, tortuous artery that runs through the submucosa of the stomach without a primary ulcer.
  • Artery measures 1-3 mm and is typically found near the gastroesophageal junction along the lesser curvature.
  • The lesion develops as the pulsations of the large submucosal artery erode the superficial mucosa. (Option C)
  • The mucosal defect is usually small, measuring 2-5 mm, and is surrounded by normal-appearing gastric mucosa. Once the artery is exposed to gastric contents, further erosion and bleeding occur.

Demographics

More common in men (2:1 ratio) and is associated with cardiovascular disease, chronic kidney disease, and diabetes.

Clinical Presentation

Sudden onset of massive, painless hematemesis (vomiting blood).

Diagnosis

Endoscopy: Primary tool, identifies lesion in 80% of cases; repeat may be needed.

Angiography: Used if endoscopy is inconclusive; shows tortuous artery and potential contrast extravasation.

Treatment

Endoscopic Therapy:

  • Bipolar electrocoagulation,
  • Heater probe thermocoagulation,
  • Injection sclerotherapy,
  • Endoscopic hemoclipping.

Angiographic Embolization:

  • Used when endoscopy fails.

Surgery:

  • Wedge resection of the stomach if other methods fail; intraoperative endoscopy or tattooing aids in locating the lesion.

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with vomiting, dehydration, and poor feeding. An abdominal X-ray shows a "double bubble" sign. Which of the following statements correctly differentiates Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis from Duodenal Atresia?

options.label: A
options.text: CHPS typically presents with bilious vomiting, while Duodenal Atresia presents with non-bilious vomiting.

options.label: B
options.text: In CHPS, infants are often hungry after vomiting, whereas in Duodenal Atresia, infants have no desire to feed.

options.label: C
options.text: Both conditions present with projectile vomiting, but CHPS is diagnosed by X-ray showing the "double bubble" sign.

options.label: D
options.text: Duodenal Atresia is commonly treated with Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy, whereas CHPS requires surgical correction of the duodenum.

questions.correct_answer: B. In CHPS, infants are often hungry after vomiting, whereas in Duodenal Atresia, infants have no desire to feed.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS)

Duodenal Atresia

Aetiology

Thickening of pyloric muscle

Congenital obstruction of the duodenum

Age of Presentation

3 to 6 weeks

Typically presents shortly after birth

Vomiting Characteristics (Option A ruled out)

Forceful, non-bilious, projectile vomiting

Bilious vomiting due to distal obstruction

Feeding Behaviour

Infants are hungry and seek re-feeding

Often no desire to feed due to persistent vomiting

Physical Exam & X-ray Findings
  • Palpable “olive-like” mass in the right upper quadrant.
  • “Single bubble” sign on X-ray.

"Double bubble" sign on X-ray; no palpable mass.

 

Diagnosis 

Clinical history, physical exam, and ultrasound

X-ray or ultrasound showing a "double bubble" sign (Option C ruled out)

Treatment (Option D ruled out)

Surgical: Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy; non-surgical not advised

Surgical: Duodenoduodenostomy or duodenojejunostomy required

questions.text: A 17 year old girl with a history of depression presents with complaints of epigastric pain, early satiety, and vomiting of blood. She elicited a history of eating her hair due to stress. On examination, a palpable epigastric mass is noted. A CT scan of the abdomen reveals a large mass in the stomach. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Trichobezoars

Phytobezoars

Definition

Hairballs formed in the stomach

Solid masses from plant fibres and seeds

Common Population

Young females with psychiatric conditions

Patients with partial gastrectomy, diabetics with neuropathy

Symptoms

Epigastric pain, early satiety, hematemesis, gastritis, loss of appetite, perforation, palpable mass

Similar symptoms, but often asymptomatic initially

Diagnosis

CT scan

CT scan or endoscopy

Primary Treatment

Surgical removal via gastrotomy

psychiatric counselling

Enzymatic digestion or surgical removal

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain following forceful vomiting. Physical examination reveals subcutaneous emphysema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Esophageal perforation

Definition

A breach in the esophageal wall leads to leakage and increased morbidity and mortality

Causes

Iatrogenic injury, spontaneous (Boerhaave's syndrome), foreign bodies, corrosive substances, eosinophilic esophagitis, esophageal cancer

Symptoms
  • Varies by cause and location:
  • Iatrogenic (recent instrumentation)
  • Boerhaave's (vomiting, chest pain, emphysema)
  • Cervical (neck pain, etc.)

Diagnosis

Imaging: Chest X-ray, contrast swallow studies, CT scan

Management
  • Seal perforation, ensure drainage, supportive measures (nutrition, cardiorespiratory support, sepsis control)
  • Conservative Management: Suitable for stable patients: antibiotics, nil by mouth, observation
  • Endoscopic Interventions: Visualization, retrieval, sealing with clips/stents, nasogastric tube placement
  • Surgical Intervention: Required for significant sepsis, large perforations, pleural involvement, delayed presentation
  • Surgical Options: Primary repair, controlled fistula creation, esophageal diversion, esophagectomy (rare)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with fatigue, difficulty swallowing and pale skin. Investigation reveals a cervical esophageal web. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Plummer Vinson Syndrome

Overview
  • A rare condition affecting middle-aged women.
  • Characterized by a triad of the cervical esophageal web, iron deficiency anemia, and dysphagia.
  • Cervical Esophageal Web
    • Thin membrane narrowing the upper esophagus
  • Iron Deficiency Anemia
    • Insufficient iron causes fatigue, shortness of breath, pale skin
  • Dysphagia: Difficulty swallowing

Causes
  • Iron/nutritional deficiencies
  • Genetic factors
  • Autoimmune conditions

Risks
  • Increased risk of post-cricoid and cervical esophageal cancer

Treatment
  • Iron supplements
  • Dietary modifications,
  • Endoscopic dilatation if necessary

questions.text: Which of the following findings are diagnostic of nutcracker esophagus? Distal esophageal contraction amplitude > 180 mmHg Distal esophageal contraction amplitude > 45 mmHg Distal esophageal peristaltic wave duration > 6 cm Distal esophageal contraction amplitude < 30 mmHg Distal esophageal contraction duration > 6 seconds Multiple simultaneous contractions with an amplitude of > 30 mmHg.
questions.explanation:
Definition

Excessively intense, coordinated esophageal contractions with normal LES function.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia (solids and liquids)
  • Severe chest pain
  • Less common regurgitation
  • Globus sensation

Investigations

Esophageal Manometry
  • High amplitude contractions (>180 mmHg)
  • Prolonged contraction duration (>6 seconds)
  • Normal LES pressure and relaxation

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

"Corkscrew" or "rosary bead" appearance due to intense contractions

Endoscopy

Typically normal mucosa

Used to rule out structural abnormalities

Management

Non-Pharmacological

Dietary Modifications: Smaller, frequent meals

Pharmacological
  • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., nifedipine)
  • Nitrates (e.g., isosorbide dinitrate)
  • Botulinum Toxin Injection

Surgical
  • Esophageal Myotomy (rare)
  • Peroral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM)
  • Severe cases may require Esophagectomy

Endoscopic

Dilation (less effective)

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia for liquids more than solids over six months, regurgitation of undigested food, nocturnal cough, and unintentional weight loss. Which investigation is the gold standard for diagnosing his condition?
questions.explanation:
Definition

It is characterized by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall. This leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus. (Option A)

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance).

 


 

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris, It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia such as tumors.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of liver cirrhosis and ascites presents to the emergency department with fever, abdominal pain, and tenderness. Paracentesis is performed, and the ascitic fluid analysis shows an elevated white blood cell count. Which of the following organisms is the most common cause of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis in patients with ascites along with its source of infection?
questions.explanation:
Type of Peritonitis

Microbial Characteristics

Primary

Monomicrobial, extraperitoneal source, blood spread

Secondary

Most common, polymicrobial, intra-peritoneal source

Tertiary

Due to superadded infection following treatment of secondary/primary

questions.text: Match the following conditions with its endoscopy images A) Esophageal candidiasis 1) B) Feline esophagitis 2) C)Herpes simplex esophagitis 3) D)CMV esophagitis 4)
questions.explanation:
Esophageal candidiasis

 

Characterized by white, raised plaques that resemble cottage cheese or curd. These plaques are adherent and often found along the entire length of the esophagus. The surrounding mucosa may appear erythematous and friable.

Feline esophagitis

 

Often presents with concentric rings, giving the esophagus a "feline" appearance,

Herpes simplex esophagitis

 

Typically presents with multiple small, well-circumscribed, punched-out ulcers. These ulcers are often located in the mid-to-distal esophagus. The surrounding mucosa may be erythematous.

CMV esophagitis

 

Characterized by large, solitary or linear ulcers, often located in the mid-to-distal esophagus. The ulcers may have a well-defined border and are surrounded by relatively normal mucosa.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with progressive dysphagia and weight loss over the past 3 months. An endoscopy reveals a tumor in the lower third of the esophagus. Biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma. Further investigation reveals, the tumor has invaded the muscularis propria but no distant metastasis is detected. Which treatment option is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Carcinoma Esophagus- Management

Staging
  • Accurate staging is essential for treatment planning.

Early-Stage Disease
  • Endoscopic Mucosal Resection (EMR): Removes superficial cancers (T1a) and early cancers with minimal submucosal invasion (T1b). (Option A ruled out)
  • Endoscopic Submucosal Dissection (ESD): Removes larger lesions with en bloc resection. (Option B ruled out)
  • Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA): Treats early Barrett's esophagus-associated cancers. Uses heat to destroy cancer cells. No surgical specimen for pathological assessment. (Option D ruled out)

Locally Advanced Disease
  • Esophagectomy: Primary treatment for locally advanced cancer. Removes esophagus and reconstructs the digestive tract using the stomach, jejunum, or colon. Surgical approaches: transhiatal, transthoracic, minimally invasive (MIE). (Option C)
  • Multimodality Therapy: Combines chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and surgery.
  • Neoadjuvant Chemoradiation: Shrinks the tumor before surgery. CROSS trial showed survival benefit for neoadjuvant chemoradiation followed by surgery.

Palliative Treatment
  • Endoscopic Stenting: Maintains esophageal patency, helps with swallowing difficulties.
  • Chemotherapy: Slows cancer progression, shrinks the tumor.
  • Radiotherapy: Shrinks tumors, controls bleeding.
  • Brachytherapy: Internal radiation therapy targeting the tumor.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a 10-year history of chronic GORD presents for a follow-up endoscopy. The endoscopy shows a 3 cm segment of salmon-colored mucosa extending above the OGJ with biopsy-proven intestinal metaplasia. He has no nodularity or ulceration. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: High-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and aspirin

questions.correct_answer: C. High-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and aspirin
questions.explanation:
Barrett's Esophagus

Definition

Complication of GORD

Columnar epithelium >1 cm above OGJ

Endoscopic Landmarks

OGJ: proximal end of gastric folds, not diaphragmatic pinch/squamocolumnar junction

Classification

Prague C&M: circumferential (C) and maximal (M) extent

Risk Factors
  • Chronic GORD
  • Age >50
  • Smoking
  • Central obesity
  • Male

Cancer Risk
  • Non-dysplastic: 0.2–0.5%/year
  • Low-grade: 0.7%/year
  • High-grade: 7%/year

Screening
  • Early identification/treatment

Treatment
  • Treat underlying GORD, same pharmacological therapy as symptomatic GORD
  • Chemoprevention: Aspirin + high-dose PPI improves outcomes (Option C)
  • Dysplastic Treatment: Ablate/resect without invasive cancer, controversial in non-dysplastic
  • Ablative Therapy: Flat lesions only, RFA preferred
  • EMR vs ESD
    • EMR: easier, piecemeal;
    • ESD: en bloc, better margins

Post-Treatment

Surveillance for recurrence/persistent Barrett's or neoplasia

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with intermittent chest pain and difficulty swallowing for the past few months. The chest pain is often severe and mimics angina but is not related to exertion. His symptoms often occur at night. Barium swallow reveals a typical finding given below. Which of the following disorders is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Uncoordinated, simultaneous contractions of the esophagus with normal LES function.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia (solids and liquids)
  • Severe chest pain
  • Less common regurgitation
  • Globus sensation

Investigations

Esophageal Manometry: Multiple simultaneous non-peristaltic contractions with an amplitude of > 30 mmHg; normal LES pressure and relaxation.
 

Barium Swallow (Esophagram): "Corkscrew" or "Rosary bead" appearance.

(Option A)
 

Endoscopy: Generally normal mucosa; rule out structural abnormalities.

Management

Non-Pharmacological: Dietary Modifications (smaller, frequent meals)
 

Pharmacological:

  • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., nifedipine)
  • Nitrates (e.g., isosorbide dinitrate)
  • Botulinum Toxin Injection
 

Surgical:

  • Esophageal Myotomy (rare)
  • Peroral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM)
 

Endoscopic: Dilation (less effective)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with refractory peptic ulcer disease is being considered for surgical intervention. Which of the following procedures will most likely preserve the vagal innervation of the gastric antrum and pylorus while reducing acid secretion?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Truncal Vagotomy

(Option A)

Truncal Vagotomy with Antrectomy

(Option C)

Selective Vagotomy

(Option B)

Highly Selective Vagotomy

Nerves Divided

Left and right vagus above hepatic and celiac branches

Truncal vagotomy plus removal of the antrum

Main right and left vagus distal to celiac and hepatic branches

Only nerves to the acid-producing portion (all branches to the fundus and body) of the stomach

Drainage Procedure

Usually required

Not applicable

Required

Not required

Acid Reduction

~50%

~85%

<50%

Variable

Ulcer Recurrence

2-7%

1%

5-10%

2-10%%

Significant side effects

10-20%

10-20%

10-20%

<5%

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the Zenker’s diverticulum?

options.label: A
options.text: An enlarged diverticulum always results in desynchronization.

options.label: B
options.text: Halitosis is a symptom of an enlarged diverticulum.

options.label: C
options.text: Protrudes posteriorly below the cricopharyngeal sphincter.

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of a suture line increases the chance of a postoperative leak.

questions.correct_answer: B. Halitosis is a symptom of an enlarged diverticulum.

questions.text: A newborn male presents with severe respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen. Chest X-ray reveals bowel loops in the left thoracic cavity. Immediate surgical intervention is planned to repair the diaphragmatic defect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Description

Failure of fusion of pleuroperitoneal canal, leading to direct communication between pleura and peritoneum on the left side

Common Contents

Colon, occasionally small bowel or stomach

Associated Conditions
  • Hypoplasia (potentially bilateral)
  • Decreased bronchial branch generation
  • Extension of tunica media beyond respiratory bronchioles
  • Decreased total lung mass

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory embarrassment
  • Scaphoid abdomen
  • Bowel sounds on the left side of the chest
  • Mediastinal shift towards the right side
  • Intestinal obstruction

questions.text: A patient presents with early satiety, weight loss, nausea, and vomiting. An upper endoscopy reveals a narrowing of the pylorus due to inflammation and scarring from peptic ulcer disease. What is the most appropriate initial step in managing this patient's gastric outlet obstruction?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgical antrectomy with reconstruction and vagotomy

options.label: C
options.text: Placement of a nasogastric tube and correction of fluid/electrolyte imbalances

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate initiation of H. pylori eradication therapy

questions.correct_answer: C. Placement of a nasogastric tube and correction of fluid/electrolyte imbalances
questions.explanation:
Gastric Outlet Obstruction (GOO) from Peptic Ulcer Disease (PUD)

GOO occurs when the passage of food from the stomach to the small intestine is blocked.

Inflammation and scarring from ulcers in the pylorus or duodenum, lead to a narrowing of the digestive tract.

Symptoms
  • Early satiety, Anorexia, Weight loss, Feeling of fullness
  • Nausea and vomiting,
  • Abdominal pain, Dilated stomach,
  • Dehydration and metabolic alkalosis (from prolonged vomiting)

Diagnosis

Primary Diagnostic Approach: Differentiate PUD vs malignancy.

  • Endoscopy: Directly visualizes the pylorus to evaluate stenosis and obtain biopsies to rule out cancer.
  • Assess for H. pylori infection. (Option D)
  • Contrast Radiology: Assesses pylorus narrowing and obstruction severity

Treatment

Initial Stabilization: (Option C)

  • Gastric Decompression: NG tube placement.
  • Fluid and Electrolyte Correction: Intravenous fluids and electrolytes.
  • Nutritional Support: Dietary modifications, enteral or parenteral nutrition.

Addressing Underlying PUD:

  • Medical Therapy: H. pylori eradication therapy, Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs).
  • Endoscopic Dilation: Dilate narrowed tract area; stent placement (Option B).

Surgical Intervention:

  • Antrectomy with Reconstruction and Vagotomy: Removal of antrum, stomach reconnection, and vagus nerve cutting (Option A).
  • Vagotomy with Drainage Procedure: Jaboulay Gastroduodenostomy, Gastrojejunostomy, Pyloroplasty.

Post-Gastrectomy Syndromes

Dumping Syndrome: Rapid emptying of food into the small intestine causing gastrointestinal and vasomotor symptoms (abdominal pain, nausea, diarrhoea, sweating, palpitations)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with severe epigastric pain and black, tarry stools. He has a history of chronic gastritis and NSAID use for osteoarthritis. Upper GI endoscopy reveals a gastric ulcer and a biopsy is taken for histological analysis. According to the modified Johnson’s criteria, what type of ulcer is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Types

Location

Acid level

Type I

Ulcer at lesser curve incisura angularis

Most common

Low to normal

Type II

Ulcer at the gastric body and

Duodenal ulcer

Increased

Type III

Ulcer is pre-pyloric

Increased

Type IV

Ulcers higher on the lesser curvature, M/C type to bleed.

Normal

Type V

Any location/throughout the stomach but NSAID-induced ulcers.

Normal

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of gastric carcinoma comes to the OPD with abdominal pain, early satiety, diarrhoea, and bloating. On examination, she is tachycardic and has palpitations. She also complains of headaches. She has undergone partial gastrectomy and Billroth type II reconstruction. What is the diagnosis here?
questions.explanation:
Early Dumping

Late Dumping
  • It is seen within 30 minutes of meals
  • Worsens with food intake
  • Relieved by lying down
  • It is seen after 1-3 hours of meals
  • Less common
  • Worsens with exercise
  • Relieved by food

Treatment: Intravenous fluids

Treatment: Oral glucose is given
